H0.text: What is the name given to a sculpted female figure serving as an architectural support taking the place of a column or a pillar. Atlantica

H1.text: What is the name given to a sculpted female figure serving as an architectural support taking the place of a column or a pillar. Statuina

H2.text: What is the name given to a sculpted female figure serving as an architectural support taking the place of a column or a pillar. Columna

H3.text: What is the name given to a sculpted female figure serving as an architectural support taking the place of a column or a pillar. Cariate

A4.text: A caryatid ( KAIR-ee-AT-id, KARR-; Ancient Greek: Καρυᾶτις, romanized: Karuâtis; pl. Καρυάτιδες, Karuátides) is a sculpted female figure serving as an architectural support taking the place of a column or a pillar supporting an entablature on her head.

A5.text: Four terracotta caryatids were used on the porch of St Pancras New Church, London (1822).

A6.text: The Acropolis Museum is conserving the Caryatids.

A7.text: There are images of Caryatids of Athens available in Spanish.

A8.text: The Greek term karyatides literally means 'maidens of Karyai', an ancient town on the Peloponnese.

A9.text: The term is first recorded in the Latin form caryatides by the Roman architect Vitruvius.
